results.title: Darling
results.creator_credit: John Schlesinger, Joseph Janni and Embassy Pictures Corporation (US)
results.brief_description: Julie Christie won an Academy Award for her performance as an ambitious young model who uses all her assets to achieve social successs. Ultimately, she finds that the life to which she aspired is meaningless and empty. Her relationships with journalist Dirk Bogarde, company director Laurence Harvey, an effeminate photographer and an Italian Prince are never really satisfying. “Darling” was groundbreaking in its time because it exposed the “swinging 60’s” with its more “modern” attitudes towards sexuality, homosexuality and infidelity in a frank and adult manner. The viewer may be left feeling that Christie’s character is shallow and cold despite her vulnerabilty, and that the emptiness of her life is of her own making.

results.title: Impromptu
results.creator_credit: James Lapine, Daniel A. Sherkow, Stuart Oken, Governor Productions, Les Films Ariane and Sovereign Pictures
results.brief_description: Two lovers could never be more different than the cross-dressing, cigar-smoking writer George Sand (Judy Davis) and the frail, romantic Frederic Chopin (Hugh Grant). The greatest creative minds of all time - including Liszt (Julian Sands), Delacroix (Ralph Brown) and de Musset (Mandy Patinkin) come together for one wild fortnight. The lustful Marie d’Agoult (Bernadette Peters) decides to amuse herself and with her mischievous scheming there is no telling who will end up with who! The outcome is scandalous even by today’s standards - an outrageous sex farce that portrays the greatest geniuses with sexual appetites as powerful as their creative fervour. Co-starring Georges Corraface, Anton Rodgers and Emma Thompson.

results.title: Deep red
results.creator_credit: Dario Argento, Rizzoli Film, Salvatore Argento and Spettacoli
results.brief_description: Dario Argento’s blood thirsty thriller stars British actor David Hemmings. Witnessing the violent murder of a young parapsychologist, Hemmings embarks on a search for the murderer by following the trail of blood and destruction. “Deep red” is a film of relentless tension, with a bizarre ending and contains some of cinema’s most gripping film sequences. Italian dialogue. Dubbed in English.

results.title: Diary of a chambermaid
results.creator_credit: Jean Renoir, Benedict Bogeaus, Burgess Meredith and Republic Films
results.brief_description: Chambermaid Celestine, (Paulette Goddard), a determined young woman wanting to improve her position and willing to use all her assets to do so. She climbs her way up through the various men in her life; her weak master Monsieur Lanlaire (Reginald Owen), his frail son George, (Hurd Hatfield), an eccentric flower-eating farmer/soldier Captain Mauger (Burgess Meredith), and the ruthless valet Joseph (Francis Lederer). What ensues is scandal, blackmail and murder. This was Renoir’s fourth American film, based on the novel by Octave Mirabeau.

results.title: Heaven's gate
results.creator_credit: Michael Cimino, Joan Carell and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: Heaven’s gate is one of the most talked-about films in cinema history and based on events which occurred in Wyoming in 1892 when ruthless ranchers decided to kill starving immigrants who had been stealing cattle. Kris Kristofferson and Christopher Walken play lawman and hitman on opposite sides of the struggle, who share the love of Ella, played by Isabelle Huppert. The original film was cut by 70 minutes and was never acclaimed in the United States as it was in Europe. This version is presented in its entirety and has compelling performances by the supporting cast of John Hurt, Jeff Bridges and Sam Waterston and locational shoots of breathtaking beauty.

results.title: Night of the living dead
results.creator_credit: Tom Savini, John Russo, Russ Steiner and 21st Century Film Corporation
results.brief_description: The producers of the original “Night of the living dead” have remade their classic horror film - this time in gruesome living colour. The story faithfully follows that of the original film - seven strangers trapped in a remote farmhouse while outside an army of undead closes in! The use of high-tech, state-of-the-art technology makes possible special effects that George A. Romero would only have dreamed of while directing the 1968 version with a below $200,000 budget. Nevertheless the dimly shot black-and-white images of the original were far creepier than their modern counterparts.

results.title: Dirty Harry
results.creator_credit: Don Siegel, Malpaso Company and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: Harry Callaghan is a tough, streetwise San Francisco cop whom they call Dirty Harry. In this classic film, you will see why. You will also see why Clint Eastwood’s reputation is secure. No other actor can match his presence. He is magnetising in his portrayal as the shoot-first-ask-questions-later law enforcer who must hunt a psychotic roof-top killer who has slain two people and has kidnapped a girl and threatens to suffocate her if his ransom demands are not met. Harry will get him… one way or the other… no matter what the “system” prescribes. Moody cinematography and stunning location filming propel the story and capitalise upon Eastwood’s commanding presence. Watch this film and ask yourself: Do you feel lucky?

results.title: Victor/Victoria
results.creator_credit: Blake Edwards, Tony Adams, Ladbroke Entertainment and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Sparkling, ultra-sophisticated entertainment from Blake Edwards. This story is based on a 1933 German comedy film “Viktor und Viktoria” written and directed by Rheinhold Schunzel. Set in Paris in 1934, it is the tale of a down-on-her luck chanteuse, played by Julie Andrews. Also suffering a temporary career lapse is tres gai nightclub entertainer (Robert Preston), who remakes her as a man who in short order becomes celebrated as Paris’s foremost female impersonator. In the process she snags the attentions of a Chicago nightclub owner (James Garner). He, however, has a small problem - is it a he or a she who has stolen his heart? 1982 Academy Award for Best Original Score (Henry Mancini). Academy Award nominations for Best Actress (Julie Andrews), Supporting Actor (Robert Preston), Supporting Actress (Lesley Anne Warren), Screenplay Adaptation, Costume Design and Art Direction.

constellations_other.name: Marlene Dietrich: queering gender onscreen
constellations_other.description: Marlene Dietrich is an icon of queer style – from her proud bisexuality to her scandalous decision to wear a tuxedo on the red carpet. This constellation explores androgyny, gender non-conformity and drag on screen in the century since Dietrich's performance in Morocco (1930).

results.title: Alice doesn't live here anymore
results.creator_credit: Martin Scorsese, Audrey Maas, David Susskind and Warner Bros Pictures
results.brief_description: In her remarkable Academy Award winning portrayal, Ellen Burstyn stars as Alice, a recently widowed housewife who packs herself and her son into a station wagon and heads off in search of a better life. Alice travels a bumpy road - no money, nowhere jobs and not much luck. She fights back with a spirited determination, which underscores this moving, often funny tale of one woman’s struggle for self-awareness and independence. With ‘Alice Doesn’t Live Here Anymore’, director Martin Scorsese shows that he is equally at home in semi-rural surroundings as he is in the asphalt jungle of ‘Taxi Driver’. The outstanding supporting cast includes Kris Kristofferson, Jodie Foster and Harvey Keitel.

results.title: Jesus Christ superstar
results.creator_credit: Norman Jewison, Robert Stigwood and Universal Pictures
results.brief_description: Andrew Lloyd Webber and Tim Rice’s rock opera, “Jesus Christ Superstar” is one of the most successful theatrical musicals of all time. The story of Jesus’s Passion is scored to a vibrant, electronic rock beat and is performed by a cast of dancers and singers. The tribal aesthetics of the hippies and the counter-culture are as integral to the work as is the story of the Gospels. Filmed on location in Israel, the movie version of the opera is a pyrotechnic feast with dazzling editing and photography. Finally, however, it is the strength of the music and libretto by which this work has to be judged. The performances of Yvonne Elliman as Mary Magdalene and Carl Anderson as Judas are outstanding. Through their singing, the full tragedy and power of the Passion is realised. Songs include” “Jesus Christ Superstar”, “What’s the Buzz” and a knockout rendition of “I Don’t Know How to Love Him” by Elliman. Melvyn Bragg co-wrote the screenplay with Norman Jewison.
